Our first prototype features the latest technological enhancement that is lightweight, multi-functional, and super flexible. We are committed to creating a timeless, eco-conscious, and wholesome brand to spark curiosity in your everyday life. We can’t thank you enough for checking out our project. If you’re a supporter of our mission, help us spread the word on Social and anywhere else you can think of!

story:
Last Day Dash

It is unbelievable,  many-maker got  funded!!!!

I was so despondent the last few days, then the community came through!!!

It is going to be amazing!!

Follow @lafrashenning



Every maker, inventor and engineer  knows that 3D printing is great for making prototypes, but after the prototype is made, you struggle to commercialize those prototypes because 3D printing is too slow and costly for production runs, and the long lead time, high cost and risk of the injection moulding tools prevents quick and easy access to industrial injection moulding processes.

Many-maker solves this problem by enabling you to make injection moulded production runs in record time, right on your desktop using inexpensive mould tools cast in high temperature polymers from mould masters made with your 3D printer.

Many-Maker is the ultimate 3D printer  accessory as it can reproduce your prints without days worth of printing, hand finishing or expensive filament.


The Many-maker automatic model in operation.


Step 1 - DFM - Design your part for manufacture (DFM), print out your prototypes and test them, once you are happy with your part then ... (ref: Basics and general info) (more about draft)


Step 2 - Prepare the master print - In your CAD package split your part on the "hairline" and attach the 2 parts to the moulding template provided, adjust sprue, gates, runners, vents and ejection pins as needed, then 3D print the two mould master tools.


Step 3 - Refine the mould master 3D prints - Depending on you printer and materials refine your print to the quality you want from your copies.


Step 4 - Cast the mould tool -  Insert the 2 part half's into the unique Many-maker 1 step rapid casting mould tool base, Mix and inject the moulding compound into the tools, let set, remove and clean.


Step 5 - Setup the injection mould press and run - Attach the mould half's to the press, set the material, quantity and volume of the part, fill the hopper and press start, your Many-Maker will automatically produce the number of copies you require while you sleep.



Each machine comes with everything you need to get started. 


Optional color mixing screw attachment - The optional color mixing screw attachment allows you to mix any color or use color master-batches to achieve an unlimited uniform color range.
The Large-Pro model:



More technical specs ...

Each press comes with everything you need to get started. 

Many-Maker- Large Pro Model - This is the more capable professional automatic production press.

Key features:

  • Style - Professional desktop appliance footprint and appearance, similar to a microwave oven.
  • Large tool cavity size - 150 mm x 80 mm x 36 mm
  • Mould tools - includes both a small mould tool kit and a large mould tool kit, to fit the compact dual servo 8 tonne toggle clamp.
  • Ventilation Control - The PRO model case design is such that the press draws in fresh air from the ejection cavity and blows all exhaust flumes out a single port fitted with a fan and ducting. A properly duct-ed Many-maker will expose you to less fumes in one hundred prints than your 3D printer will in just one.
  • Noise Control - The pro model enclosure is lined with a Mass Loaded Vinyl sound barrier keeping the sound level to about 60 dBA, comparable to the sound level of an air conditioner.
  • Supplied with  0.9 kg silicone moulding material and 1kg epoxy moulding material (enough for about 8 to 12 small mould tools) and 4 kg ABS white plastic.
This model is suitable for regular production runs or moulding larger parts in a professional environment.


Many-Maker Large Automatic model -

To keep the Large Automatic model as affordable as possible we have stripped down the Pro model to a bare bones large maker machine:

  • no enclosure / cosmetic covers - Bare bones -
  • No ventilation control - needs to be used in a well ventilated area.
  • No noise control - the maximum sound level is about 72dBA - a little louder than a dishwasher.

This model is suitable for regular production runs of larger parts in an maker environment, where higher noise levels and ventilation is not an issue



Many-Maker Automatic model -

To keep the automatic model as affordable as possible we have scaled down the Large Automatic model to a smaller maker machine:

  • small tool only
  • smaller servo motors
  • smaller, single servo inline automatic 4 tonne clamp
  • smaller power supply and drive circuits

This model is suitable for regular production runs of smaller parts in an maker environment, where higher noise levels and ventilation is not an issue, and space is not at a premium.



Many-Maker - Manual Model -  To make this lowest cost model, we have scaled down the maker model even further:

  • no Automatic hopper - You measure and feed the pellets manually.
  • no Automatic clamp - The tool is opened manually.
  • no Ejector or Ejector pins - The part is removed manually.
  • only 0.9 kg silicone moulding material and 2 kg ABS white plastic.

This model is suitable for education, experimentation, prototyping, or occasional  small production runs of smaller parts.


Common Features

  • Shot size - 28 cc or 21 gram ( 3/4 oz) ABS.
  • Production Rate - can process 210 gram of raw material in 1 hour .
  • Cycle time - 10 Shots per hour at 21 gram and a single shot can consist of multiple small parts. Up to 40 Shots per hour at less than 10.5 grams per shot.
  • Small tool cavity size - 80 mm x 50 mm x 36 mm (all models )
  • Daylight - 160 mm
  • PID automation and control - Full electronic feedback and control of all system functions.
  • All electronic - Clean and silent operation using servo actuators, not hydraulic actuators.
  • All Stainless steel construction for life long reliable operation in the harshest environments.
  • Expected serviceable life - more than 50 000 production cycles.
  • Safety features - the temperature is under PID control with sensor fail detection and the hot zone is completely enclosed in a fireproof steel enclosure with all surfaces actively cooled by fans and safe to touch. 
    Jam detect stops the press if anything goes wrong, and the automatic clamp won't operate when the safety door is open.
  • Connectivity - WiFi modem, and an App so you can fine tune settings and monitor all the vital signs from anywhere in the world.
  • Open source software - Makers can modify their own machines.
  • Technical support - Online video tutorials, Design for manufacture guide, community forum and direct email support. 


Optional plasticizing screw attachment -Many-Maker uses a piston and barrel to melt and build pressure so you have to use pre-colored plastic which come in a wide but limited color range. The optional plasticizing screw attachment allows you to use uncolored plastic and color master-batches to achieve an unlimited uniform color range.

Tool making materials After extensive testing, the best starter material was found to be MoldMax 60. It is hard enough withstand the pressure for simple mounds and soft enough to make casting easy  and sets in a few hours. It is very forgiving of errors in draft so is great for making characters and irregular shapes.

For more precise and mechanical parts we supply a easy to cast but hard aluminium filled 2 part polyurethane resin. Remember the harder the casting material, the less forgiving it will be on draft errors.

Once you have the basics down, you can move onto harder and  stronger materials such as resins. Harder materials are great for more precise mechanical parts.

A wide range of casting materials can be used as long as they have limited shrinkage, their "shoreA hardness" is 60 or more and their  thermalconductivity is below 5 W/(m K). The exposure to high temperature is only for a very short duration so you can use just about any non thermo-forming plastic, especially if you can fill it with aluminium powder.

For CNC-able high precision moulds, you can use PTFE which has excellent machine-ability or PEEK which has a hardness and strength  to rival aluminium.

CNC'ed aluminium and steel can also be used on small parts.

In time, the Many-Maker community and wiki  will gain insight and practical advice on how to use a variety of materials.





The benefits of using a Desktop Injection Moulding Press as a 3D printer accessory are:

 Convenience and automation - You can automatically produce hundreds of Injection moulded copies while you sleep, and they require much less post processing finishing than 3D printed parts.

Consistent Quality and Appearance  - Once the 3D master print has been refined with careful   post processing finishing, all future injection moulded copies will have the same finish



Speed - Not fast like an industrial machine, but lightning fast compared to 3D printing multiple copies - produce 1000++ copies in a week, and it is practical to set up a Many-maker farm and achieve thousands of copies a day for much less than an industrial injection moulding tool. 
 
 Time to market - Many-Maker may be slow compared to industrial machines but it gets a small production run done quicker because it does not require metal tooling, there is no waiting in someone else's queue to get the job done, you do it right here, right now.

 Strong solid plastic - Injection molded parts are a lot stronger than printed parts, and as this study by Michael Rosplock shows, there is "no real (strength) benefit to annealing 3D printed parts" .

Known food safety -  3D printing and 3D printed parts have known and unknown toxicity issues ( 3D printing & food safety), whereas the safety of injection moulded materials are well established.

Inspirational -  Many-maker provides a self defined path from idea to market, and this self defined path is the driving inspiration for many makers.

Lowest unit cost - Compared to 3D printing Many-maker uses industrial pellets which cost less than 1/8th the price of filament. Further cost savings add up in supervision labor, machine printing time and finishing labor. Compared to industrial injection moulding, when the tooling costs, short run premiums and opportunity costs of long lead times are taken into account the total cost of production on a Many-maker is lower than industrial scale injection moulding for small to medium production runs.


More benefits ...

Competitive Benefits

The benefits of the Many-Maker press compared to small bench drill style manual injection presses:

Automation - Many-maker is automated, it can produce your parts while you sleep. Bench drill style presses are only manual, they need your full attention.

Labor saving and scale-able - a bench style press requires a dedicated person to operate just one press, with a Many-maker a single person can put an army of presses to work to create a really fast production line, and still do other work.

Process control - Many-maker's injection process is automated giving fine repeated control over the quality, Bench drill style presses are totally manual resulting in human scale variation in the process and quality.

Desktop appliance style - Many-maker pro sits neatly next to your printer, it looks and performs more like an appliance than a workshop machine.

One part molding - The unique split mould casting system make creating your mould tool a simple, cheap desktop operation.

Master batch color mixing - With the plasticizing screw attachment you can uniformly mix your own colors from master batches.



"The Many-Maker could be hugely important for some 3D printer operators," - Fabbalo

"Many-Maker bridges the gap for makers in terms of prototyping and producing quantity."  - 3DPrint.com

     

    


This is a un-edited close-up video of the ejector of the prototype machine viewed from below as it produces 3 gears, the production machines will be about twice as fast. (click here to open full screen)


As this is still a prototype the servos are manually controlled. The motors are pushed to their limit, until they stall. I have busted quite a few motor bearings under manual control. The production unit's electronics and process control firmware will take care of the motors so you cannot overload them.

A gear produced in the above video 
The gear is made from uncolored nylon which is semi-translucent so it shows up as slightly, discolored with speckles of black because the prototype still controlled manually, so it is easy to burn the plastic, and once there is burned residue in the barrel it takes a long time for it to purge. The production units will be fully controlled by the automation firmware so this will not happen.

A close up view of the edge of the gear:



According to How Much Can You Print with a Single 1kg Spool it took 14 days to print 392 chess pieces, Making and selling limited edition themed chess sets (like a this one ) could be quite a nice little business for creative makers, but not if it takes more than a day to print just one set. Using Many-Maker one set would take a little over an hour to produce.  



A Florida company, Origin Robotics is currently running a Indiegogo campaign for their Robot Hand called  ORIGIGRIP. One perk on offer is $59 for 6 printed parts and some bolts, nuts and other bits. Five of the printed parts could easily be reproduced with a Many-maker, thereby increasing the strength of the parts so they could be made smaller and lighter. Using a Many-maker would accelerate their manufacturing to enable wider distribution and most importantly reduce the cost..

Overall using a Many-maker would benefit the makers and consumers of the ORIGIGRIP.



More use cases ...

Custom electronic enclosure and buttons,

Over the years I have had lots of ideas for electronic gadgets. Only one thing has stopped me from pursuing them, "darn that would require a custom case, I have the budget for the electronics but not the kind of cash you need for a cool case and buttons", or my features will beat the imported types if only it looked better than the plain hobby boxes and buttons. With Many-Maker there is no more such limitations I can produce by own fancy enclosures and buttons.

Crowdfunded robot - A complex creation like a robot can be made up of  hundreds of custom parts, each requiring a metal injection moulding tool, and each tool will cost a couple thousand dollars , thus injection molding such a complex creation could easily cost a few hundred thousand dollars in tooling alone.  A crowdfunded project would need to sell tens of thousands of robots to be successful. What if you only sell 500? When using 3D printed tools on an industrial machine the unit cost is high because they require a slow production cycle on an expensive industrial machine. Professionally 3D printing all the parts will be to costly, printing them yourself will take to long. The answer is to only 3D print a few of the larger or more complex parts, and the rest a team of Many-maker presses can easily deliver in under a month, all for less than what a single industrial tool could cost, and a lot faster too. Many-maker makes this a viable project.



Self published games - You may have a great idea for a cool board game with unique characters. Printing cards and boards are not so expensive but if you wanted your own 3D characters, dice and paraphernalia you were in for big bucks, but now with a Many-Maker you can make your game a reality.


Mobile case - Getting a new mobile phone model case on the shelf before importers can land the new models can give you a first mover advantage. 3D printing a case will cost about $8 however the retail price for cases are around $6, leaving no margin for profit. By using Many-maker your material cost is well under 10c, the machine time and non recurring engineering costs are negligible, and time to market is hours. Many-maker makes this a viable project.

3D printing service industry (3D hubs)- If you are already offering 3D printing as a service, you will know how many prototypes you print for aspiring inventors, you will also realize how few of these actually end up being commercially produced. Offering desktop injection molding as a service to your customers will increase your potential revenue and ensure you have happy repeat customers. There will be a gold rush period where you can make high margins and good money from desktop injection moulding, as it becomes more popular the margins will drop, so make sure you establish your reputation before anyone else.



All exposed hot surfaces are actively cooled by fans and are safe to touch. The head of the machine has a protective polycarbonate shield and the press will not move without this in place.   However Many-Maker is a power tool, not a consumer appliance, to avoid injury, the operator requires similar supervision or experience as for any other  power tool.



I have to stress, Many-Maker is not a consumer product, it is a machine I build for other makers like me, wanting to learn new skills and expand on their capabilities. If you want an appliance that going to "cook" your 3D prints for you the first time out the box, then Many-maker is not  for you. You will have many failed attempts at producing your own injection moulding parts before you start winning, but once you win you will have a valuable new tool and skill set.

You could profit from your new skills by offering Injection Moulding as a extra service on 3D hubs or similar. By being an early adopter you can differentiate yourself and establish your reputation before anyone else. There will be a gold rush period where you can make high margins and good money from the desktop injection moulding service industry.

Your ability to produce a quality injection moulded part will be highly dependent on the quality of the moulding tool you create, which in turn is dependent on the manufacturing technology.

3D Printers with good surface finish ( DLP, SLA, SLS, Polly Jet) are the best solution and can easily produce both hard silicone and Epoxy tools.

FDM Printers are suitable for easily producing hard silicone moulds. Producing Epoxy tools from FDM printed mould masters requires a lot of surface finishing which can be difficult to achieve with fine detail or dimensional accuracy.

Hard Silicone Tools are suitable for parts with slight overhangs that do not require dimensional perfection such as artistic pieces. Silicone is very forgiving of poor surface finishing so is the best option for FDM printed mould masters. [Images]

Epoxy Tools are suitable for parts with no overhangs, good draft and smooth surfaces, they can produce dimensional stable and accurate parts. Best for hi resolution printers. Can be used with very well finished FDM printed mould masters without fine detail. [Images]

Laser cut layered tools are suitable for producing mechanically accurate and functional parts such as gears. Layers can be laser cut Plywood, aluminium or stainless steel sheets. [Images]

CNC tools

Bench top CNC tooling in PTFE or Aluminium will give the best possible result for all parts.



Many-Makers are quite heavy machines, there is a lot of stainless steel in these machines, they are built to last. 
The shipping charges are for direct shipping via surface mail.

World wide Shipping is $79 for the manual machine, $119 for the Automatic machine and $159 for the Pro machine.

Over the years I have established working relationships with several electronics and laser cutting contract manufacturers capable of fulfilling any quantity ordered, the great thing about laser cut steel is the exact repeatability that comes from the digital cut files, so manufacture can easily be moved to the USA at short notice.


3D printing is getting more refined, faster and cheaper than injection moulding, so why should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

The cost of fast industrial production speed 3D printers are prohibitive to have on your desktop. Comparisons like this, showing 3D printing narrowing the cost gap are based on industrial injection moulding and tooling. Many-maker desktop injection moulding radically changes this game, it is unbeatable in terms of total cost per unit.

I have seen or used resin casting for replicating my prints, why should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

Resin casting is unrivaled in some purposes and special effects, however it is a very manual and costly process compared to desktop injection moulding.

A lot of companies like Protolabs offer services for doing low number injection moulding runs, so why  should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

Protolabs use full size injection moulding machines and are capable of produce much larger parts than a desktop injection moulding machine ever could.

Their tooling costs starts at about $1495 per mould, which is really cheap compared to most services, and manufacturing time  is up to 2 weeks which is also fast for the industry.

However I am targeting way below this - tooling costs at a few $ per mould and delivery under 8 hours. The only drawback of a desktop injection mounding machine is the limited size of the part.



More non technical FAQ ...

Many-maker sounds under priced, are you sure you are able to deliver at such a low price?

The pricing has been carefully worked out at 2.6 x the material cost and labour (less Indiegogo and early bird discounts) which is in line with the recommendations of Ten rules for maker businesses (2.6 x multiplier). We keep costs down as follow: 1) No middle man taking a significant cut means we can offer an Indiegogo and early bird discount, 2) Clever practical design, 3) Using Laser cut mechanical parts instead of CNC'ed machined parts, 4) Using Desktop Injection Moulded parts wherever possible, 6) Using COTS (Common of the shelf parts) as much as possible, 7) Re-purposing mechanical sub-assemblies from mass produced automotive products and 8) The key mechanics comes fully assembled and tested but the cosmetics comes in kit form, this saves both labor and shipping.

Where do I buy after market materials?

Either from Many-Maker as a kit or from independent sources. The molding compound is widely available, and online from smooth-on (Mold Max 60). Raw plastic is available from sellers locally wherever there is industrial injection moulding industries, usually in 25KG bags at under $2 per kg. - one bag will last you a long time. We are going to build a database of regional suppliers and suitable casting and plastic materials.


Is it difficult to use?

You love 3D printing because you like challenges, you like learning new things, so yes there is a lot to learn, it is a wonderful experience to learn to make and produce your own creations, but it is not easy. You will have some failed attempts before you start winning.


Where can I get more background information on injection moulding?

A few of my favorite resources are : Scientific Moulding Pocket guide, PITFALLS IN INJECTION MOULDING OF PLASTICS, Guerrilla guide.


Can you give an example of a cost comparison?

Using an online cost estimator for industrial injection moulding we can compare costings for a very simple part.


The same part produced with a Many-Maker-PRO would be:

Material: $0.075 per part

Production : <$0.01 in electricity + TCO of MM01PRO ($0.1) per part

Tooling: Total $5 in printing and mould tool casting materials.

Total : $181 - Plus: Your labour of about 4 hours.

How would you compare industrial injection moulding with desktop injection moulding?

When desktop publishing emerged in the late 80's it was not compared to industrial printing presses, in the same way it would be wrong to compare the injection moulding machines as they are vastly different. An industrial professional can look at desktop injection moulding as say that it is so limiting, a maker, inventor or entrepreneur can look at the same machine and say it is so liberating. Its performance is totally subjective.

What about technical support?

In addition to the online video tutorials, I will also have direct online support. I hope to establish an online community around desktop injection moulding to expand and share knowledge and experiences.

Faulty parts and spares will have to be ordered online, having said that the machine is very robust so I expect most issues to be user related, or mould making related.

I run a 3D printing service, can I offer injection moulding as an add on?

Yes, This is a great business opportunity as the cost benefit of desktop injection moulding is unparalleled for small production runs. I expect initially there will be a gold rush period during which the initial adopters will make high profit margins, followed by a plateau and eventually nearly all 3D printing service providers will offer low cost injection mould production.


Can I injection mould non 3D printed parts or crafts?

Yes, you can make suitable 2 part moulds from just about any object.

I have seen industrial injection moulding machines on auction for $1K to $5K, why should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

What I want to achieve is to put a production machine for under $1000 in the hands of makers, together with all the material, tools and know-how in one box - a system to follow and learn from. It is not about putting a single machine in a few hands, it is about putting a new skill in lots of hands.

However, If you are lucky enough to find such a machine, and you can afford it then you should buy it, but remember it takes up a lot of space, and maintenance and repair is going to be at industrial machine prices not auction prices, so best you make sure it is complete and in full working condition.

Why are you trying to minimize the role of 3D printing in democratized manufacture?

If I reach my objective of widespread adoption of desktop injection moulding then Many-Maker will be a 3D printing amplifier, and 3D printing will become more influential in the market due to Many-Maker's benefits. More makers will see a self defined path from idea to market, and this self defined path is the driving inspiration for many makers.

What happens when my mould tool gets worn out in just a couple of hundred shots?

Just make another tool (from the same 3D master print), it is quick and quite cheap ($3 to $5) depending on size.

More technical FAQ ...

How does Many-Maker fit the function of a big industrial machine into a desktop press ?

An industrial machine is optimized for high speed production with many cavities and fast cycle times, so it injects plastic melt with between 800 psi and 12000 psi (big machines even higher), For an industrial machine the typical cycle time is under 15 seconds and it can accommodate a large tool that can make multiple (4x 8x 16x or even 100x) small parts in one shot.

Many-Maker injects with between 600 psi and 3000 psi into the casted mould tool. Many-maker has a cycle time of 300 seconds and it can accommodate a tool about 1/8th to 1/4 the size of a typical small industrial machine, and would typically make only one part at a time.

High pressure industrial machines can achieve long 0.5 mm and thinner walls, with most walls being around 2 mm and runners at 3 mm diameter. With a many-maker we have to compromise by using thicker walls and runners. Many-Maker can still achieve high definition, just not very long thin walls.


Many-Maker may be slow but it gets a small production run done quicker because there are no delays in waiting for metal tooling, or queuing for a production run.

I know you need metal tools to withstand the pressure from injection moulding, how can you do it with silicone rubber?

Firstly we are limited to smaller tools and parts, that reduces the pressure requirement. Secondly, because silicone has a 50x lower thermal conductivity than steel we don't need to re-heat the melt in the mould tool, using sheer-thinning pressure and gates techniques, thus the pressure requirement is much lower.

Compared to metal, Shore 60A silicone is very soft, but because it is quite dense, when you compress it in a small metal enclosure, it is surprisingly resistant. The plastic will flow where there is least resistance so we have built in overflow routes so back pressure is limited, and when the pressure subsides from the initial injection, the silicone pushes back and keeps its form reasonably and predictably well - ideal for characters, Meeples and irregular shapes. For precision mechanical parts the use of hard resin cast moulds or CNC'ed metal moulds are recommended. Alas there will be some features that is possible with metal tooling that will require compromises and workarounds with polymer tooling.

What is the largest part I can make?

The largest mould cavity for the PRO model is 150 mm x 90 mm x 36 mm, However the largest part will depend on the length and thickness of the runners and walls, and the compromises you make. If the part you need is larger you can still make it by bonding, welding or riviting multiple small parts together.


A 28 cc or 21 gram shot seems tiny and useless, why did you make it so small?

The shot size compares well to other small machines like this or this, which cost much more than what Many-maker costs. A 28 cc (0.7 oz) shot size is a lot larger than what you may think, so it far from useless, there are plenty of applications where 28 cc is ample. A final product could be made of multiple parts, some produced by Many-maker, some professionally 3D printed, and some even laser cut from steel, acrylic or wood. Many-maker is part of the ecosystem, you will find ways to to create your product. The size is limited by the budget for the servo's and toggle clamp.

Can I injection mould everything or anything I printed?

No, you have to Design For Manufacture ( DFM ), this means you have to follow similar constraints to full industrial injection moulding, else your part will remain stuck in the mould! 3D printing is capable of producing objects that injection moulding could never reproduce, so you have to work within the limits of the technology.

What types of plastics can be used?

A well designed mould tool cast in Moldmax 60 and pressed in ABS will give you a mould tool life of about 500 shots, but just about any plastic with a melt temperature between 150'C and 290'C can be used. Higher temperature plastics, filled plastics like carbon fiber and highly corrosive plastics will reduce the the mould tool life. The good thing is if your tool gets worn out, just make another, it is quick and quite cheap.

Can I modify my own machine?

The software will be open sourced so makers can modify their own machines, it is super simple, main thing is to control the heating profile for different materials - it is nothing like the complexity of 3D printing, it is simple process control.


Why is the clamp so much bigger than the injector? / Why is the more capable PRO model, smaller than the Automatic model?

It is the norm in injection moulding for the toggle clamp to be bigger and stronger than the injector, this is to counter the force due to the leverage of the large surface area of the mould (like this effect). The Automatic model is designed for reduced cost so a single inline actuator is aligned dead center with the spru, this makes the machine a lot longer than the desktop version, which uses 2 actuators in a C toggle clamp arrangement, which requires more steel but delivers more clamping and results in a optimal use of space.


Can I use CNC'ed aluminum moulding tools or tools printed from steel or ceramics?

CNC'ed PEEK or PTFE is a better option for high endurance, high precision moulds that would work perfectly in a many-maker.

Ceramics should work very well.

Yes, metal moulds can be used but the maximum size may be smaller than what can be achieved with PEEK or PTFE.

More printer FAQ ...

Do I need a special printer or to print in any special material?

No, you can print a mould master in any material using any 3D printer technology, the magic happens when you cast the mould master into a mould tool. However the surface quality of the print your printer produces will affect what you can produce.

Can I print the mould directly?

To print a mould directly you will require a thermosetting mould material, that means you need a STL or SLS printer. I think the possibilities are endless and this is probably going to be the best method of producing mould tools for desktop injection moulding.


Do I need special software?

No, you can use the same software you use to run your current 3D jobs. I plan to have mould templates available for the most common 3D software. Even if you use something different, the mould templates are quite simple geometric shapes that you can recreate easily in your software.



Currently I am on prototype revision 5. 
I have had some experience in commissioning moulded enclosures for previous electronic projects, and  I worked closely with the tool makers, so I thought I had quite a good grasp of the basic technology when I started, but it has been a steep learning curve and has taken 6 months of full time research and development to get to this point. Now finally all the mechanics are working under manual control. It's not perfect yet, and much can still be tuned and improved. Currently I am experimenting with different plastics and casting materials. The last remaining major step is to prefect the servo electronics and write the automation firmware and smartphone software.

I hope to raise enough support to order parts in bulk and to ship the first full production batch in June. 


The biggest risk is delays due to component shortage, which could delay delivery by 4 to 8 weeks. Shipping delays is a secondary risk and may add 2 to 4 weeks.


With your help I hope to democratize injection moulding, put it in the hands of self motivated  makers and thereby  start a new sub-movement in the maker movement, I want to help empower makers to produce products that can compete on unit cost with mass-produced products.

Part of  your funding will be used to buy the expensive testing equipment needed to characterize many of the process parameters such as melt pressure and clamp force, currently these are estimated figures based on comparative performance.


Funding goals:

This is a "fixed funding" project so if I do not receive the needed support the project will be cancelled so please spread the word  and help make this happen.

$25 000  Get the first many-makers assembled  and shipped to the customers.  Finish the mobile app to connect locally or remotely to your Many-Maker, to monitor and control every detail of the operation.

$50 000 Stretch goal - a full production run at an economic scale, enables me to add an extra 0.9 kg moulding material and an extra 2 kg ABS resin to all machines.

$100 000+ Stretch goal - move the manufacturing to the USA. It does not make sense to ship tonnes of laser cut stainless steel across the Atlantic. I'd love to live and build Many-Makers in the USA, and experience the culture for a few months. Depending on the cost savings every supporter will get an extra perk.



My name is Lafras, a lifelong tinkerer, maker and sometimes inventor, but mostly an analyst programmer (developer as we are known these days). I have been a self-employed entrepreneur for the last 23 years, I own a beautiful home with my wife and I live and work in wonderful KZN, South Africa.

Right from childhood I have always loved building stuff for myself,  to share and sell, but budget and availability of parts was always a problem, until I discovered programming, On my ZX81 (a.k.a. Timex Sinclair 1000) I could create anything in 1KB RAM, share it with friends and all it cost was a cassette tape, Programming has been my life, but I have always yearned for the day when I can make real things, real cheap, share them or make a profit. Inventor reborn. My story is not unique, and I am sure you feel the same way, together we can make more things, many many more things.


If you are not a maker or entrepreneur, but know a cousin or friend that is, please let them know about my project, it can really make a difference in their lives, careers and businesses.

Democratized manufacture is going to affect all our lives in the near future, it is an interesting and newsworthy subject, so please share this project with all your friends using the Indiegogo share buttons.

Many thanks

Lafras
story_txt:
Last Day Dash
It is unbelievable,  many-maker got  funded!!!!

    I was so despondent the last few days, then the community came
    through!!!

    It is going to be amazing!!
Follow @lafrashenning




Every maker, inventor and engineer  knows that 3D printing is great for making prototypes, but after the prototype is made, you struggle to commercialize those prototypes because 3D printing is too slow and costly for production runs, and the long lead time, high cost and risk of the injection moulding tools prevents quick and easy access to industrial injection moulding processes.
Many-maker solves this problem by enabling you to make injection moulded production runs in record time, right on your desktop using inexpensive mould tools cast in high temperature polymers from mould masters made with your 3D printer.Many-Maker is the ultimate 3D printer  accessory as it can reproduce your prints without days worth of printing, hand finishing or 
expensive filament.


The Many-maker automatic model in operation.




Step 1 - DFM - Design your part for manufacture (DFM), print out your prototypes and test them, once you are happy with your part then ... (ref: Basics and general info) (more about draft)


Step 2 - Prepare the master print - In your CAD package split your part on the "hairline" and attach the 2 parts to the moulding template provided, adjust sprue, gates, runners, vents and ejection pins as needed, then 3D print the two mould master tools.



Step 3 - Refine the mould master 3D prints - Depending on you printer and materials refine your print to the quality you want from your copies.

Step 4 - Cast the mould tool -  Insert the 2 part half's into the unique Many-maker 1 step rapid casting mould tool base, Mix and inject the moulding compound into the tools, let set, remove and clean.



Step 5 - Setup the injection mould press and run - Attach the mould half's to the press, set the material, quantity and volume of the part, fill the hopper and press start, your Many-Maker will automatically produce the number of copies you require while you sleep.





Each machine comes with everything you need to get started. 




Optional color mixing screw attachment - The optional color mixing screw attachment allows you to mix any color or use color master-batches to achieve an unlimited uniform color range.

The Large-Pro model:










More technical specs ...


Each press comes with everything you need to get started. 
Many-Maker- Large Pro Model - This is the more capable professional
    automatic production press.
Key features:


Style - Professional desktop appliance footprint and appearance,
      similar to a microwave oven.

Large tool cavity size - 150 mm x 80 mm x 36 mm

Mould tools - includes both a small mould tool kit and a large mould
      tool kit, to fit the compact dual servo 8 tonne toggle clamp.


Ventilation Control - The PRO model case design is such that the
      press draws in fresh air from the ejection cavity and blows all exhaust flumes out
      a single port fitted with a fan and ducting. A properly duct-ed Many-maker will
      expose you to less fumes in one hundred prints than your 3D printer will in just
      one.

Noise Control - The pro model enclosure is lined with a Mass
      Loaded Vinyl sound barrier keeping the sound level to about 60 dBA, comparable to
      the sound level of an air conditioner.

Supplied with  0.9 kg silicone moulding material and 1kg epoxy
      moulding material (enough for about 8 to 12 small mould tools) and 4 kg ABS white
      plastic.
This model is suitable for regular production runs or moulding larger parts in a
    professional environment.

Many-Maker Large Automatic model -
To keep the Large Automatic model as affordable as possible we have stripped down
    the Pro model to a bare bones large maker machine:

no enclosure / cosmetic covers - Bare bones -
No ventilation control - needs to be used in a well ventilated area.
No noise control - the maximum sound level is about 72dBA - a little louder
      than a dishwasher.

This model is suitable for regular production runs of larger parts in an maker
    environment, where higher noise levels and ventilation is not an issue


Many-Maker Automatic model -
To keep the automatic model as affordable as possible we have scaled down the
    Large Automatic model to a smaller maker machine:

small tool only
smaller servo motors
smaller, single servo inline automatic 4 tonne clamp
smaller power supply and drive circuits

This model is suitable for regular production runs of smaller parts in an maker
    environment, where higher noise levels and ventilation is not an issue, and space is
    not at a premium.


Many-Maker - Manual Model -  To make this lowest cost model, we have
    scaled down the maker model even further:

no Automatic hopper - You measure and feed the pellets manually.
no Automatic clamp - The tool is opened manually.
no Ejector or Ejector pins - The part is removed manually.
only 0.9 kg silicone moulding material and 2 kg ABS white plastic.

This model is suitable for education, experimentation, prototyping, or occasional
     small production runs of smaller parts.

Common Features


Shot size - 28 cc or 21 gram ( 3/4 oz) ABS.

Production Rate - can process 210 gram of raw material in 1 hour
      .

Cycle time - 10 Shots per hour at 21 gram and a single shot can
      consist of multiple small parts. Up to 40 Shots per hour at less than 10.5 grams
      per shot.

Small tool cavity size - 80 mm x 50 mm x 36 mm (all models )

Daylight - 160 mm

PID automation and control - Full electronic feedback and control
      of all system functions.

All electronic - Clean and silent operation using servo actuators,
      not hydraulic actuators.

All Stainless steel construction for life long reliable operation
      in the harshest environments.

Expected serviceable life - more than 50 000 production
      cycles.

Safety features - the temperature is under PID control with sensor
      fail detection and the hot zone is completely enclosed in a fireproof steel
      enclosure with all surfaces actively cooled by fans and safe to touch. 
      Jam detect stops the press if anything goes wrong, and the automatic clamp won't
      operate when the safety door is open.

Connectivity - WiFi modem, and an App so you can fine tune settings
      and monitor all the vital signs from anywhere in the world.

Open source software - Makers can modify their own machines.

Technical support - Online video tutorials, Design for manufacture
      guide, community forum and direct email support. 



Optional plasticizing screw attachment -Many-Maker uses a piston and barrel
    to melt and build pressure so you have to use pre-colored plastic which come in a
    wide but limited color range. The optional plasticizing screw attachment allows you
    to use uncolored plastic and color master-batches to achieve an unlimited uniform
    color range.
Tool making materials After extensive testing, the best starter material
    was found to be MoldMax 60. It is hard enough withstand the pressure for
    simple mounds and soft enough to make casting easy  and sets in a few hours. It
    is very forgiving of errors in draft so is great for making characters and irregular
    shapes.
For more precise and mechanical parts we supply a easy to cast but hard aluminium
    filled 2 part polyurethane resin. Remember the harder the casting material, the less
    forgiving it will be on draft errors.
Once you have the basics down, you can move onto harder and  stronger
    materials such as resins. Harder materials are great for
    more precise mechanical parts.
A wide range of casting materials can be used as long as they have limited
    shrinkage, their "shoreA hardness" is 60 or more and their  thermalconductivity is below 5 W/(m K). The exposure
    to high temperature is only for a very short duration so you can use just about any
    non thermo-forming plastic, especially if you can fill it with aluminium powder.
For CNC-able high precision moulds, you can use PTFE which has excellent
    machine-ability or PEEK which has a hardness and strength  to rival
    aluminium.
CNC'ed aluminium and steel can also be used on small parts.
In time, the Many-Maker community and wiki  will gain insight and practical
    advice on how to use a variety of materials.






The benefits of using a Desktop Injection Moulding Press as a 3D printer accessory are:









Convenience and automation - You can automatically produce hundreds of Injection moulded copies while you sleep, and they require much less post processing finishing than 3D printed parts.









Consistent Quality and Appearance  - Once the 3D master print 
has been refined with careful   post processing finishing, all future 
injection moulded copies will have the same finish










Speed - Not fast like an industrial machine, but lightning fast compared to 3D printing multiple copies - produce 1000++ copies in a week, and  it is practical to set up a Many-maker farm and achieve thousands of copies a day for much less than an industrial injection moulding tool. 
 







 Time to market - Many-Maker may be slow compared to industrial machines but it gets a small production run done quicker because it does not require metal tooling, there is no waiting in someone else's queue to get the job done, you do it right here, right now.








 Strong solid plastic -  Injection molded parts are a lot stronger than  printed parts, and as this study by Michael Rosplock   shows, there is "no real (strength) benefit to annealing 3D printed parts" . 









Known food safety -  3D printing and 3D printed parts have known and unknown toxicity issues ( 3D printing & food safety), whereas the safety of injection moulded materials are well established.








Inspirational -  Many-maker provides a self defined path from idea to market, and this self defined path is the driving inspiration for many makers.








Lowest unit cost - Compared to 3D printing Many-maker uses industrial pellets which cost less than 1/8th the price of filament. Further cost savings add up in supervision labor, machine printing time and finishing labor. Compared to industrial injection moulding, when the tooling costs, short run premiums and opportunity costs of long lead times are taken into account the total cost of production on a Many-maker is lower than industrial scale injection moulding for small to medium production runs.






More benefits ...
Competitive Benefits
The benefits of the Many-Maker press compared to small bench drill style manual injection presses:
Automation - Many-maker is automated, it can produce your parts while you sleep. Bench drill style presses are only manual, they need your full attention.
Labor saving and scale-able - a bench style press requires a dedicated person to operate just one press, with a Many-maker a single person can put an army of presses to work to create a really fast production line, and still do other work.
Process control - Many-maker's injection process is automated giving fine repeated control over the quality, Bench drill style presses are totally manual resulting in human scale variation in the process and quality.
Desktop appliance style - Many-maker pro sits neatly next to your printer, it looks and performs more like an appliance than a workshop machine.
One part molding - The unique split mould casting system make creating your mould tool a simple, cheap desktop operation.
Master batch color mixing - With the plasticizing screw attachment you can uniformly mix your own colors from master batches.





"The Many-Maker could be hugely important for some 3D printer operators," - Fabbalo
"Many-Maker bridges the gap for makers in terms of prototyping and producing quantity."  - 3DPrint.com

  

  




    



This is a un-edited close-up video of the ejector of the prototype machine viewed from below as it produces 3 gears, the production machines will be about twice as fast. (click here to open full screen)




As this is still a prototype the servos are manually controlled. The motors are pushed to their limit, until they stall. I have busted quite a few motor bearings under manual control. The production unit's electronics and process control firmware will take care of the motors so you cannot overload them.A gear produced in the above video The gear is made from uncolored nylon which is semi-translucent so it shows up as slightly, discolored with speckles of black because the prototype still controlled manually, so it is easy to burn the plastic, and once there is burned residue in the barrel it takes a long time for it to purge. The production units will be fully controlled by the automation firmware so this will not happen.
A close up view of the edge of the gear:



According to How
Much Can You Print with a Single 1kg Spool it
took 14 days to print 392 chess pieces, Making and selling limited
edition themed chess sets (like a this
one )
could be quite a nice little business for creative makers, but not if
it takes more than a day to print just one set. Using Many-Maker one
set would take a little over an hour to produce.  





A Florida company, Origin Robotics is currently running a Indiegogo campaign for their Robot Hand called  ORIGIGRIP. One perk on offer is $59 for 6 printed parts and some bolts, nuts and other bits. Five of the printed parts could easily be reproduced with a Many-maker, thereby increasing the strength of the parts so they could be made smaller and lighter. Using a Many-maker would accelerate their manufacturing to enable wider distribution and most importantly reduce the cost..
Overall using a Many-maker would benefit the makers and consumers of the ORIGIGRIP.





More use cases ...


Custom electronic enclosure and buttons,Over the years I have had lots of ideas for electronic gadgets. Only one thing has stopped me from pursuing them, "darn that would require a custom case, I have the budget for the electronics but not the kind of cash you need for a cool case and buttons", or my features will beat the imported types if only it looked better than the plain hobby boxes and buttons. With Many-Maker there is no more such limitations I can produce by own fancy enclosures and buttons.Crowdfunded robot - A complex creation like a robot can be made up of  hundreds of custom parts, each requiring a metal injection moulding tool, and each tool will cost a couple thousand dollars , thus injection molding such a complex creation could easily cost a few hundred thousand dollars in tooling alone.  A crowdfunded project would need to sell tens of thousands of robots to be successful. What if you only sell 500? When using 3D printed tools on an industrial machine the unit cost is high because they require a slow production cycle on an expensive industrial machine. Professionally 3D printing all the parts will be to costly, printing them yourself will take to long. The answer is to only 3D print a few of the larger or more complex parts, and the rest a team of Many-maker presses can easily deliver in under a month, all for less than what a single industrial tool could cost, and a lot faster too. Many-maker makes this a viable project.
Self published games - You may have a great idea for a cool board game with unique characters. Printing cards and boards are not so expensive but if you wanted your own 3D characters, dice and paraphernalia you were in for big bucks, but now with a Many-Maker you can make your game a reality.
Mobile case - Getting a new mobile phone model case on the shelf before importers can land the new models can give you a first mover advantage. 3D printing a case will cost about $8 however the retail price for cases are around $6, leaving no margin for profit. By using Many-maker your material cost is well under 10c, the machine time and non recurring engineering costs are negligible, and time to market is hours. Many-maker makes this a viable project.3D printing service industry (3D hubs)- If you are already offering 3D printing as a service, you will know how many prototypes you print for aspiring inventors, you will also realize how few of these actually end up being commercially produced. Offering desktop injection molding as a service to your customers will increase your potential revenue and ensure you have happy repeat customers. There will be a gold rush period where you can make high margins and good money from desktop injection moulding, as it becomes more popular the margins will drop, so make sure you establish your reputation before anyone else.





All exposed hot surfaces are actively cooled by fans and are safe to touch. The head of the machine has a protective polycarbonate shield and the press will not move without this in place.   However Many-Maker is a power tool, not a consumer appliance, to avoid injury, the operator requires similar supervision or experience as for any other  power tool.








I have to stress, Many-Maker is not a consumer product, it is a machine I build for other makers like me, wanting to learn new skills and expand on their capabilities. If you want an appliance that going to "cook" your 3D prints for you the first time out the box, then Many-maker is not  for you. You will have many failed attempts at producing your own injection moulding parts before you start winning, but once you win you will have a valuable new tool and skill set.

You could profit from your new skills by offering Injection Moulding as a extra service on 3D hubs or similar. By being an early adopter you can differentiate yourself and establish your reputation before anyone else. There will be a gold rush period where you can make high margins and good money from the desktop injection moulding service industry.





Your ability to
produce a quality injection moulded part will be highly dependent on
the quality of the moulding tool you create, which in turn is
dependent on the manufacturing technology. 





3D Printers with
good surface finish ( DLP,  SLA, SLS, Polly Jet) 
are
the best solution and can easily
produce both hard silicone
and Epoxy tools.


FDM Printers
are suitable for easily
producing hard
silicone moulds. Producing
Epoxy tools from FDM printed
mould masters requires a lot
of surface finishing which can be difficult to achieve with fine
detail or dimensional accuracy.


Hard Silicone
Tools are suitable for parts with slight overhangs that do
not require dimensional perfection such as artistic pieces. Silicone
is very forgiving of poor surface finishing so is the best option for
FDM printed mould masters. [Images]



Epoxy Tools are suitable for parts with no overhangs, good
draft and smooth surfaces, they can produce dimensional stable and
accurate parts. Best for hi resolution printers. Can be used with
very well finished FDM printed mould masters without fine detail. 
[Images]


Laser cut layered
tools are suitable for producing mechanically accurate and
functional parts such as gears. Layers can be laser cut Plywood,
aluminium or stainless steel sheets.  [Images]


CNC tools
Bench top CNC
tooling in PTFE or Aluminium will give the best possible result for
all parts.








Many-Makers are quite heavy machines, there is a lot of stainless steel in these machines, they are built to last. 


The shipping charges are for direct shipping via surface mail.








World wide Shipping is  $79 for the manual machine, $119 for the Automatic machine and $159 for the Pro machine.

Over the years I have established working relationships with several electronics and laser cutting contract manufacturers capable of fulfilling any quantity ordered, the great thing about laser cut steel is the exact repeatability that comes from the digital cut files, so manufacture can easily be moved to the USA at short notice.













3D
printing is getting more refined, faster and cheaper than injection moulding, so why should I bother with desktop injection
moulding?

The
cost of fast industrial production speed 3D printers are prohibitive
to have on your desktop.
Comparisons like
this, showing
3D printing narrowing the cost gap are based on industrial injection moulding and tooling. Many-maker desktop injection moulding radically changes this game,
it is unbeatable in terms of total cost per unit.



I
have seen or used resin casting for replicating my prints, why should
I bother with desktop injection moulding?

Resin
casting is unrivaled in some purposes and special effects,
however it is a very manual and costly process compared to desktop
injection moulding.
A lot of companies like Protolabs offer services for doing low number injection moulding runs, so why  should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

Protolabs use full size injection moulding machines and are capable of produce much larger parts than a desktop injection moulding machine ever could.
Their tooling costs starts at about $1495 per mould, which is really cheap compared to most services, and manufacturing time  is up to 2 weeks which is also fast for the industry.
However I am targeting way below this - tooling costs at a few $ per mould and delivery under 8 hours. The only drawback of a desktop injection mounding machine is the limited size of the part.





More non technical FAQ ...




Many-maker
sounds under priced, are you sure you are able to deliver at such a
low price?

The
pricing has been carefully worked out at 2.6 x the material cost and
labour
(less Indiegogo and early bird discounts) which is in line with the
recommendations of Ten
rules for maker businesses (2.6 x multiplier).
We keep costs down as follow: 1) No middle man taking a significant
cut means we can offer an Indiegogo and early bird discount, 2)
Clever practical design, 3) Using Laser cut mechanical parts instead
of CNC'ed machined parts, 4) Using Desktop Injection Moulded parts
wherever possible, 6) Using COTS (Common of the shelf parts) as much
as possible, 7) Re-purposing mechanical sub-assemblies from mass
produced automotive products and 8) The key mechanics comes fully
assembled and tested but the cosmetics comes in kit form, this saves
both labor and shipping.



Where
do I buy after market materials?

Either
from Many-Maker as a kit or from independent sources. The molding
compound is widely available, and online from smooth-on (Mold
Max 60).
Raw plastic is available from sellers locally wherever there is
industrial injection moulding industries, usually in 25KG bags at
under $2 per kg. - one bag will last you a long time. We are going to
build a database of regional suppliers and suitable casting and
plastic materials.



Is
it difficult to use?

You
love 3D printing because you like challenges, you like learning new
things, so yes there is a lot to learn, it is a wonderful experience
to learn to make and produce your own creations, but it is not easy.
You will have some failed attempts before you start winning.

Where
can I get more background information on injection moulding?

A
few of my favorite resources are : Scientific
Moulding Pocket guide, PITFALLS
IN INJECTION MOULDING OF PLASTICS, Guerrilla
guide.

Can
you give an example of a cost comparison?

Using an
online cost estimator for industrial injection moulding we
can compare costings for a very simple part.






The
same part produced with a Many-Maker-PRO would be:

Material:
$0.075 per part

Production
: <$0.01 in electricity + TCO of
MM01PRO ($0.1) per part

Tooling:
Total $5 in printing and mould tool casting materials.

Total
: $181 - Plus: Your labour of about 4 hours.



How
would you compare industrial injection moulding with desktop
injection moulding?

When
desktop publishing emerged in the late 80's it was not compared to
industrial printing presses, in the same way it would be wrong to
compare the injection moulding machines as they are vastly different.
An industrial professional can look at desktop injection moulding as
say that it is so limiting, a maker, inventor or entrepreneur can
look at the same machine and say it is so liberating. Its performance
is totally subjective.



What
about technical support?

In
addition to the online video tutorials, I will also have direct
online support. I hope to establish an online community around
desktop injection moulding to expand and share knowledge and
experiences.

Faulty
parts and spares will have to be ordered online, having said that the
machine is very robust so I expect most issues to be user related, or
mould making related.



I
run a 3D printing service, can I offer injection moulding as an add
on?

Yes,
This is a great business opportunity as the cost benefit of desktop
injection moulding is unparalleled for small production runs. I
expect initially there will be a gold rush period during which the
initial adopters will make high profit margins, followed by a plateau
and eventually nearly all 3D printing service providers will offer
low cost injection mould production.

Can
I injection mould non 3D printed parts or crafts?

Yes,
you can make suitable 2 part moulds from just about any object.











I
have seen industrial injection moulding machines on auction for $1K
to $5K, why should I bother with desktop injection moulding?

What
I want to achieve is to put a production machine for under $1000 in
the hands of makers, together with all the material, tools and
know-how in one box - a system to follow and learn from. It is not
about putting a single machine in a few hands, it is about putting a
new skill in lots of hands.

However,
If you are lucky enough to find such a machine, and you can afford it
then you should buy it, but remember it takes up a lot of space, and
maintenance and repair is going to be at industrial machine prices
not auction prices, so best you make sure it is complete and in full
working condition.



Why
are you trying to minimize the role of 3D printing in democratized
manufacture?

If
I reach my objective of widespread adoption of desktop injection
moulding then Many-Maker will be a 3D printing amplifier, and 3D
printing will become more influential in the market due to
Many-Maker's benefits. More makers will see a self defined path from
idea to market, and this self defined path is the driving inspiration
for many makers.



What
happens when my mould tool gets worn out in just a couple of hundred
shots?

Just
make another tool (from the same 3D master print), it is quick and
quite cheap ($3 to $5) depending on size.



More technical FAQ ...






How
does Many-Maker fit the function of a big industrial machine into a
desktop press ?

An
industrial machine is optimized for high speed production with many
cavities and fast cycle times, so it injects plastic melt with
between 800 psi and 12000 psi (big machines even higher), For an
industrial machine the typical cycle time is under 15 seconds and it
can accommodate a large tool that can make multiple (4x 8x 16x or
even 100x) small parts in one shot.

Many-Maker
injects with between 600 psi and 3000 psi into the casted mould tool.
Many-maker has a cycle time of 300 seconds and it can accommodate a
tool about 1/8th to 1/4 the size of a typical small industrial
machine, and would typically make only one part at a time.

High
pressure industrial machines can achieve long 0.5 mm and thinner
walls, with most walls being around 2 mm and runners at 3 mm
diameter. With a many-maker we have to compromise by using thicker
walls and runners. Many-Maker can still achieve high definition, just
not very long thin walls.

Many-Maker
may be slow but it gets a small production run done quicker because
there are no delays in waiting for metal tooling, or queuing for a
production run.



I
know you need metal tools to withstand the pressure from injection
moulding, how can you do it with silicone rubber?

Firstly
we are limited to smaller tools and parts, that reduces the pressure
requirement. Secondly, because silicone has a 50x lower thermal
conductivity than steel we
don't need to re-heat the melt in the mould tool, using
sheer-thinning pressure and gates techniques,
thus the pressure requirement is much lower.

Compared
to metal, Shore 60A silicone is very soft, but because it is quite
dense, when you compress it in a small metal enclosure, it is
surprisingly resistant. The plastic will flow where there is least
resistance so we have built in overflow routes so back pressure is
limited, and when the pressure subsides from the initial injection,
the silicone pushes back and keeps its form reasonably and
predictably well - ideal for characters, Meeples and
irregular shapes. For precision mechanical parts the use of hard
resin cast moulds or CNC'ed metal moulds are recommended. Alas there
will be some features that is possible with metal tooling that will
require compromises and workarounds with polymer tooling.





What
is the largest part I can make?

The
largest mould cavity for the PRO model is 150 mm x 90 mm x 36 mm,
However the largest part will depend on the length and thickness of
the runners and walls, and the compromises you make. If the part you
need is larger you can still make it by bonding, welding or riviting
multiple small parts together.

A
28 cc or 21 gram shot seems tiny and useless, why did you make it so
small?

The
shot size compares well to other small machines like this or this,
which cost much more than what Many-maker costs. A 28 cc (0.7 oz)
shot size is a lot larger than what you may think, so it far from
useless, there are plenty of applications where 28 cc is ample. A
final product could be made of multiple parts, some produced by
Many-maker, some professionally 3D printed, and some even laser cut
from steel, acrylic or wood. Many-maker is part of the ecosystem, you
will find ways to to create your product. The size is limited by the
budget for the servo's and toggle clamp.



Can
I injection mould everything or anything I printed?

No,
you have to Design For Manufacture ( DFM ), this means you have to
follow similar constraints to full industrial injection moulding,
else your part will remain stuck in the mould! 3D printing is capable
of producing objects that injection moulding could never reproduce,
so you have to work within the limits of the technology.



What
types of plastics can be used?

A
well designed mould tool cast in Moldmax 60 and pressed in ABS will
give you a mould tool life of about 500 shots, but just about any
plastic with a melt temperature between 150'C and 290'C can be used.
Higher temperature plastics, filled plastics like carbon fiber and
highly corrosive plastics will reduce the the mould tool life. The
good thing is if your tool gets worn out, just make another, it is
quick and quite cheap.







Can
I modify my own machine?

The
software will be open sourced so makers can modify their own
machines, it is super simple, main thing is to control the heating
profile for different materials - it is nothing like the complexity
of 3D printing, it is simple process control.

Why
is the clamp so much bigger than the injector? / Why is the more
capable PRO model, smaller than the Automatic model?

It
is the norm in injection moulding for the toggle clamp to be bigger
and stronger than the injector, this is to counter the force due to
the leverage of the large surface area of the mould (like
this effect).
The Automatic model is designed for reduced cost so a single inline
actuator is aligned dead center with the spru, this makes the machine
a lot longer than the desktop version, which uses 2 actuators in a C
toggle clamp arrangement, which requires more steel but delivers more
clamping and results in a optimal use of space.





Can
I use CNC'ed aluminum moulding tools or tools printed from steel or
ceramics?

CNC'ed
PEEK or PTFE is a better option for high endurance, high precision
moulds that would work perfectly in a many-maker.

Ceramics
should work very well.

Yes,
metal moulds can be used but the maximum size may be smaller than
what can be achieved with PEEK or PTFE.




More printer FAQ ...


Do
I need a special printer or to print in any special material?

No,
you can print a mould master in any material using any 3D printer
technology, the magic happens when you cast the mould master into a
mould tool. However the surface quality of the print your printer produces will affect what you can produce.



Can
I print the mould directly?

To
print a mould directly you will require a thermosetting mould
material, that means you need a STL or SLS printer. I think the
possibilities are endless and this is probably going to be the best
method of producing mould tools for desktop injection moulding.

Do
I need special software?

No,
you can use the same software you use to run your current 3D jobs. I
plan to have mould templates available for the most common 3D
software. Even if you use something different, the mould templates
are quite simple geometric shapes that you can recreate easily in
your software.





Currently I am on prototype revision 5. 

I have had some experience in commissioning moulded enclosures for previous electronic projects, and  I worked closely with the tool makers, so I thought I had quite a good grasp of the basic technology when I started, but it has been a steep learning curve and has taken 6 months of full time research and development to get to this point. Now finally all the mechanics are working under manual control. It's not perfect yet, and much can still be tuned and improved. Currently I am experimenting with different plastics and casting materials. The last remaining major step is to prefect the servo electronics and write the automation firmware and smartphone software.

I hope to raise enough support to order parts in bulk and to ship the first full production batch in June. 
The biggest risk is delays due to component shortage, which could delay delivery by 4 to 8 weeks. Shipping delays is a secondary risk and may add 2 to 4 weeks.




With your help I hope to democratize injection moulding, put it in the hands of self motivated  makers and thereby  start a new sub-movement in the maker movement, I want to help empower makers to produce products that can compete on unit cost with mass-produced products.
Part of  your funding will be used to buy the expensive testing equipment needed to characterize many of the process parameters such as melt pressure and clamp force, currently these are estimated figures based on comparative performance.

Funding goals:
This is a "fixed funding" project so if I do not receive the needed support the project will be cancelled so please spread the word  and help make this happen.
$25 000  Get the first many-makers assembled  and shipped to the customers.  Finish the mobile app to connect locally or remotely to your Many-Maker, to monitor and control every detail of the operation.
$50 000 Stretch goal - a full production run at an economic scale, enables me to add an extra 0.9 kg moulding material and an extra 2 kg ABS resin to all machines.


$100 000+ Stretch goal - move the manufacturing to the USA. It does not make sense to ship tonnes of laser cut stainless steel across the Atlantic. I'd love to live and build Many-Makers in the USA, and experience the culture for a few months. Depending on the cost savings every supporter will get an extra perk.



My name is Lafras, a lifelong tinkerer, maker and 
sometimes inventor, but mostly an analyst programmer (developer as we 
are known these days). I have been a self-employed entrepreneur for the 
last 23 years, I own a beautiful home with my wife and I live and work 
in wonderful KZN, South Africa.Right from childhood I have always 
loved building stuff for myself,  to share and sell, but budget and availability of parts was always a problem, until I discovered 
programming, On my ZX81 (a.k.a. Timex Sinclair 1000) I could create anything in 1KB RAM, share it with friends 
and all it cost was a cassette tape, Programming has been my life, but I
 have always yearned for the day when I can make real things, real 
cheap, share them or make a profit. Inventor reborn. My story is not unique, and I am sure you feel the same way, together we can make more things, many many more things.
If you are not a maker or entrepreneur, but know a cousin or friend that is, please let them know about my
 project, it can really make a difference in their lives, careers and businesses.
Democratized manufacture is going to affect all our lives in the near future, it is an interesting and newsworthy subject, so please share this project with all your friends using the Indiegogo share buttons.

Many thanks
Lafras

story:
Risks and challenges

Delivery time: In manufacturing, there's always a risk that suppliers do not fulfill orders on time. We're working with a manufacturer that is very professional and organized. We are working closely with them to make sure production goes smoothly. In any case, we will do what we can to deliver before the expected delivery dates!

Duty/VAT charges: If you live outside of the Eu, you will be responsible for any applicable duty/VAT charges.

Customs: Some countries are known for being very slow with customs, and you probably know if you live in one. We're sorry that we can't put a magic stamp on our packages to help them get through faster.

We'll update you frequently about our progress, and if there are any blips along the way, we'll let you know!
